H0.text: Killing viruses is the most likely use for the gene therapy that replaces abnormal human genes with healthy copies of the same genes, a method made possible by technological advances allowing scientists to develop such replacement techniques.

H1.text: Healing wounds is the most likely use for gene therapy methods that replace abnormal human genes with healthy copies of the same genes, made possible by technological advances.

H2.text: Treatment of airborne infections is the most likely use for gene therapy that replaces abnormal human genes with healthy copies of the same genes, a method enabled by technological advances.

H3.text: Treatment of inherited diseases is the most likely use for this gene therapy, where technological advances enable scientists to develop methods for replacing abnormal human genes with healthy copies of the same genes.

A4.text: Gene therapy could be used to deliver a copy of this gene that does not contain the deleterious mutation and thereby produces a functional protein.

A5.text: Ashanthi DeSilva was treated for ADA-SCID.
